sentence: Retail stocks fell to their lowest level in more than eight months today, prompting one investor to bet against the Retail HOLDRS exchange-traded fund.
optionMONSTER's tracking systems detected heavy activity of the August 9 calls, which traded 5,213 times against open interest of just 223 contracts.
Most of the volume priced in a single block for $2.15 as the RTH fought its way back from the lows.
The RTH, which holds stakes in companies such as Wal-Mart and Home Depot, fell 2.22 percent to $87.15 in morning trading.
Earlier in the session the ETF touched $86.39, its lowest price since early October.
The fund has been trending lower since mid-April as investors unload stocks in the economically sensitive consumer-discretionary sector.
Selling calls now reflects a belief that the RTH will remain below $90 through expiration, though the trades will make money as long as it doesn't climb above $92.15.
It may have been implemented by a shareholder who wants to exit the sector while earning a small amount of extra income from selling volatility.
Upcoming news could also affect the RTH because important employment data comes the next three mornings: the ADP report tomorrow, initial-jobless claims Thursday and non-farm payrolls on Friday.
The news could influence investors' outlook for consumer spending and retail sales.
Overall options volume in the RTH is more than twice the average level so far today, with the call sales accounting for most of the activity.
